supporting_text: The NAP is tricyclic consistent with a 'One Health' approach involving human and non-human sectors.
The NAP mentions specific actions in the human health sector, including improving AMR awareness among authorities and the public.
The NAP includes actions aimed at controlling antimicrobial use in animals and reinforcing OIE biosafety laws.
The NAP addresses environmental health through the involvement of the Ministry of Environment and actions related to environmental health.
The NAP includes actions related to controlling antimicrobial use in agriculture and food security.
The NAP includes a monitoring and evaluation plan to track progress.
The NAP outlines specific activities and timelines for implementation over the next five years.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
The NAP does not specify budget allocations for the strategies or actions.
The NAP does not contain an assessment of future budget requirements.
The NAP establishes a National Multi-sectoral Coordination Group for AMR control.
The NAP mentions the need to reinforce available related legislations that were neglected during the years of conflict.
The NAP includes actions to include AMR awareness in school curricula and training for healthcare professionals.
The NAP includes strategies for public awareness campaigns about AMR.
The NAP mentions collaboration with WHO, FAO, and OIE for AMR initiatives.
The NAP includes actions to initiate an AMR surveillance system.
The NAP includes capacity building for laboratories to detect and report AMR.
The NAP includes strategies for improving infection prevention and control (IPC) in healthcare systems.
The NAP mentions the need to reinforce OIE biosafety laws in the veterinary world.
The NAP includes actions to regulate the dispensing of antibiotics and maintain essential medicine lists.
The NAP includes strategies to control the use of antibiotics in the community and restrict dispensing to prescription-based practices.
The document does not specify participation in international collaborative research for new medicines or vaccines.
